intro: Cephaelis vultusmimi, commonly known as the "Face of the Devil" or "Devil's Face," is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 12,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its striking, velvety purple flowers that resemble a human face, giving it its ominous common name. It thrives in high-altitude environments with cool, moist conditions. Due to its unique appearance and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
